Headline.Para: Saudi Crown Prince Will Seek to Solidify Anti-Iran Stance With Trump White House; Prince Mohammed is likely to emphasize his effort to modernize the ultraconservative petrostate

Corrections.Para: Saudi Arabia's Prince Mohammed bin Salman is campaigning to make the closed petrostate into a modern country that is open to business. An earlier version of this article referred to Saudi Arabia as an open petrostate. (March 21, 2018)

LeadPara.Para: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman arrives Monday in Washington, D.C., bringing the brash foreign policy that has shaped Saudi Arabia's more muscular stance in the Middle East to counter archenemy Iran.

The Trump administration and lawmakers now need to weigh whether to support the prince's more confrontational approach with Iran and risk sparking a regional conflict, or seek to moderate his diplomacy.

TailParas.Para: "The key question," says Brian Katulis, a fellow at the Center for American Progress, a Washington think tank, "is how does America best shape Saudi Arabia and influence how it engages?"

For years, the U.S. could count on the kingdom to anchor its agenda in the Middle East. In exchange for U.S. military protection, Saudi Arabia guaranteed a steady supply of oil and provided a bastion of stability in a volatile region.

Prince Mohammed upended that status quo after his father, King Salman, assumed the throne three years ago. At home, the father-and-son duo have sought to transform the kingdom's economy, ending its reliance on oil. And abroad, Saudi Arabia has abandoned the kingdom's traditionally passive foreign policy in favor of trying to roll back Iran's pervasive influence—an approach that has dragged it into a devastating war next door in Yemen.

Prince Mohammed's hard-line stance on Iran has resonated with the Trump administration. Mr. Trump—who traveled to the kingdom last May in his first trip abroad as president—has aligned with Saudi Arabia by threatening to scrap a multination deal with Iran that froze its nuclear program in exchange for easing sanctions. Mr. Trump is scheduled to meet Prince Mohammed on Tuesday, in the prince's first visit to the U.S. since he became heir to his father's throne last year.

The replacement of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson with Central Intelligence Agency Director Mike Pompeo is expected to give a boost to those in the Trump administration looking to more forcefully confront Iran.

"From a Saudi perspective, Pompeo is an upgrade from Tillerson," said Hani Sabra, founder of Alef Advisory, a New York-based political-risk firm. On Iran "Mohammed bin Salman is going to encounter a very receptive White House."

A more empowered Saudi Arabia, in theory, could add pressure on Iran to curb its involvement in Arab countries and lead efforts to combat religious extremism in the region by using its clout as the birthplace of Islam. In practice, Prince Mohammed's more assertive foreign policy posture has often backfired.

Qatar is a case in point. Saudi Arabia and its closest allies sparked the worst political crisis among Gulf countries in decades when they severed diplomatic relations and imposed an economic embargo on Qatar in June.

The Saudi-led bloc, which includes the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Bahrain, want Qatar to stop meddling in regional affairs by severing its support for Islamist groups like the Muslim Brotherhood. They also accuse it of being too close to Iran and of having ties to terror groups, which Doha denies. Qatar, home to the biggest U.S. base in the Middle East, has dismissed the requests as an infringement on its sovereignty.

High on the agenda for the U.S. during Prince Mohammed's visit is persuading Saudi Arabia to reconcile with Qatar ahead of a possible summit in Camp David in May. Previous U.S. efforts have failed, and hopes of a breakthrough remain slim.
"We have to make some kind of headway on resolving the dispute if we are going to have the summit," said one State Department official.

The Saudi-led bloc says reconciling with Qatar isn't a priority. "It's hard to counter instability when one of your supposed partners says they are with you, but they are stabbing you behind your back," said a Saudi official. "The dispute with Qatar is best resolved through the mediation process that is led by Kuwait. And that will be our message in Washington."

Saudi Arabia's three-year war in Yemen, which has killed thousands of civilians and pushed the country to the brink of famine, will be another focus in Washington, where the prince is also meeting Republican and Democratic leaders in both houses of Congress.
The Senate is expected to vote on a resolution calling on the U.S. to cut off military aid to the Saudis because of Yemen—a move the Pentagon is opposing.

Mr. Trump and Prince Mohammed are also expected to discuss an evolving deal by the U.S. to sell nuclear reactors to Saudi Arabia. Some U.S. officials want to make sure any agreement prevents Saudi Arabia from using the civilian project to develop a nuclear weapon.

Saudi Arabia says that it wants nuclear power for peaceful purposes, as it tries to become less dependent on oil. But it doesn't want to rule out the possibility of eventually having nuclear weapons, either.

"Saudi Arabia does not want to acquire any nuclear bomb, but without a doubt if Iran developed a nuclear bomb, we will follow suit as soon as possible," Prince Mohammed said in an interview with CBS's "60 Minutes" aired Sunday.

Perhaps the crown prince's best weapon to assuage U.S. concerns about its more aggressive role in the region is to play up his efforts to combat extremism from Saudi Arabia. He has sought to lead by example by pushing for social change in one of world's most conservative countries, which is the custodian of Islam's holiest sites.

During his nearly three-week tour—which includes stops in New York, Silicon Valley and Houston—Prince Mohammed can emphasize his campaign to turn a closed petrostate into a modern country that is open to business and eager for investment. He can point to moves like the coming end to the ban on women driving, and plans for a public sale of a small portion of Saudi Aramco, the state-owned oil giant. The schedule, which is subject to change, includes meetings with tech executives at Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Apple Inc., among others, according to people briefed on the visit. The Saudi delegation is also planning to visit some of the biggest U.S. defense contractors: Lockheed Martin Corp., Boeing Co. and Raytheon Co.

In Los Angeles, the Saudis will scout for entertainment investment opportunities as the kingdom prepares to lift its ban on cinemas. On the agenda are meetings at Walt Disney Co. and Comcast Corp.'s Universal Pictures.
Saudi Arabia's allies have welcomed change in the kingdom, even as they remain wary of the consequences of Prince Mohammed's more impulsive decision making.

"There's a good deal of support in Washington for the crown prince's transition programs," says Lori Plotkin Boghardt, a Gulf states expert at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. "Frankly, I think one of the main concerns right now is that the kingdom remains stable."
Summer Said in Dubai contributed to this article.
